    Hello Products

    hello_products.Rmd

    Read Models

    Here we read the target product model, prod, and its two factor models, si and age, into R.

    prod = Compartmental(prod_dir)
si = Compartmental(si_dir)
age = Compartmental(age_dir)

    The goal of this document is to multiply si and age to see if we can recover our target, prod.

    Simulating from the Product Model

    TODO:

    • Do the model definition by hand so that it works
    • Specify numerical inputs
    • Run the the simulation
    • Verify the results

    Multiplying Variable Lists

    We begin taking the product of si and age by multiplying the variables, which are as follows for the factor models.

    si$variables()
#>              Epi
#> 1              S
#> 2              I
#> 3              N
#> 4      infection
#> 5         waning
#> 6 susceptibility
#> 7        contact
#> 8    infectivity
age$variables()
#>     Age
#> 1 young
#> 2   old
#> 3 aging

    The simple Cartesian product of these two lists is as follows.

    cartesian(si$variables(), age$variables())
#>               Epi   Age
#> 1               S young
#> 2               I young
#> 3               N young
#> 4       infection young
#> 5          waning young
#> 6  susceptibility young
#> 7         contact young
#> 8     infectivity young
#> 9               S   old
#> 10              I   old
#> 11              N   old
#> 12      infection   old
#> 13         waning   old
#> 14 susceptibility   old
#> 15        contact   old
#> 16    infectivity   old
#> 17              S aging
#> 18              I aging
#> 19              N aging
#> 20      infection aging
#> 21         waning aging
#> 22 susceptibility aging
#> 23        contact aging
#> 24    infectivity aging

    This is too much. For example, one of the levels of each state variable (S, I) in the si model is the aging rate. This doesnâ€™t make sense. Perhaps it would be better to start with the Cartesian product of the state variables only, and then build up from there.

    cartesian(si$state_variables(), age$state_variables())
#>   Epi   Age
#> 1   S young
#> 2   I young
#> 3   S   old
#> 4   I   old

    Thatâ€™s better, but it is missing the stratification of the flow rates and their parameters. For example we want age-stratified infection rates. To stratify the flows in si by the states in age we could do the following.

    cartesian(si$flow_variables(), age$state_variables())
#>         Epi   Age
#> 1 infection young
#> 2    waning young
#> 3 infection   old
#> 4    waning   old

    Thatâ€™s good. Do we want to stratify the flows in age by the states in si?

    cartesian(si$state_variables(), age$flow_variables())
#>   Epi   Age
#> 1   S aging
#> 2   I aging

    Here it doesnâ€™t make sense for S and I to age at different aging rates. But maybe for the purposes of â€˜The Product Modelâ€™ this is OK, and the user just needs to set the aging rate as constant? Not sure.

    Putting this all together we have.

    union_vars(
  cartesian(si$state_variables(), age$state_variables()),
  cartesian(si$flow_variables(), age$state_variables()),
  cartesian(si$state_variables(), age$flow_variables())
)
#>          Epi   Age
#> 1          S young
#> 2          I young
#> 3          S   old
#> 4          I   old
#> 5  infection young
#> 6     waning young
#> 7  infection   old
#> 8     waning   old
#> 9          S aging
#> 10         I aging

    But what about other variables that are neither states nor flows? We can at least list these other variables.

    si$other_variables()
#>              Epi
#> 1              N
#> 2 susceptibility
#> 3        contact
#> 4    infectivity
age$other_variables()
#> Warning in age$other_variables(): 
#> There are no other variables in this model
#> except for state and flow variables.
#> NULL

    Here we see N, which as we will see later is the sum of S and I. We also see three variables (susceptibility, contact, and infectivity) that parameterize the infection rate. Finally we also see that the only variables in the age model are states and flows.

    We want N to be stratified by age, but what about the infection-related variables? We take one at a time.

    The susceptibility parameter is a property of the from states involved in infection flows. It measures how susceptible the from state is to being infected. Often susceptibility will equal 1 (or some other constant) if there is only one susceptible state or if all susceptible states are equally susceptible. But if the susceptible states differ in their susceptibility (e.g.Â due to differeneces in vaccination status or infection history), then the susceptibility parameter will vary. In our working example we might want to stratify susceptibility by age so that young people are less susceptible than old people.

    The infectivity parameter is a property of the infectious states involved in infection flows. As with the susceptibility parameter, we probably also want to stratify infectivity by age as well.

    The contact parameter is a property of a pair of states â€“ in particular one susceptible state and one infectious state. Because all states can be any age and that it is possible for any individual in one age to interact with an individual in another age, this contact parameter needs to be stratified by age twice â€“ first by the susceptible age and then by the infectious age. This double-stratification makes contact more complex to handle, because we are not able to just take a single Cartesian product â€“ we need to take two products.

    But before we do any double products, letâ€™s first handle N, susceptibility, and infectivity.

    cartesian(
  si$other_variables()$filter("N", "susceptibility", "infectivity"), 
  age$state_variables()
)
#>              Epi   Age
#> 1              N young
#> 2 susceptibility young
#> 3    infectivity young
#> 4              N   old
#> 5 susceptibility   old
#> 6    infectivity   old
    cartesian(
  si$other_variables()$filter("contact"),
  age$state_variables()
)$products$cartesian(age$state_variables())
#>     Age     Epi
#> 1   old contact
#> 2 young contact

    Simulating the Resulting Product Model

    Scratch 

    prod$state_labels()
#> [1] "S.young." "S.old."   "I.young." "I.old."
prod$flow_labels()
#> [1] "waning.young."         "waning.old."           "infection.young.young"
#> [4] "infection.old.young"   "infection.young.old"   "infection.old.old"
    si$variables()
#>              Epi
#> 1              S
#> 2              I
#> 3              N
#> 4      infection
#> 5         waning
#> 6 susceptibility
#> 7        contact
#> 8    infectivity
si$flows_expanded()
#>   from to      flow       type
#> 1    S  I infection per_capita
#> 2    I  S    waning per_capita
    age$variables()
#>     Age
#> 1 young
#> 2   old
#> 3 aging
age$flows_expanded()
#>    from  to  flow       type
#> 1 young old aging per_capita
    prod$variables()
#>               Epi   Age  Age2  AgeS  AgeI
#> 1               S young                  
#> 2               S   old                  
#> 3               N young       young      
#> 4               N   old         old      
#> 5          waning young                  
#> 6          waning   old                  
#> 7     infectivity young             young
#> 8  susceptibility   old         old      
#> 9  susceptibility young       young      
#> 10    infectivity   old               old
#> 11              I young             young
#> 12              I   old               old
#> 13        contact young young young young
#> 14        contact   old young   old young
#> 15      infection young young young young
#> 16      infection   old young   old young
#> 17        contact   old   old   old   old
#> 18        contact young   old young   old
#> 19      infection young   old young   old
#> 20      infection   old   old   old   old
prod$flows_expanded()
#>       from       to                  flow       type
#> 1 S.young. I.young. infection.young.young per_capita
#> 2 S.young. I.young.   infection.young.old per_capita
#> 3   S.old.   I.old.   infection.old.young per_capita
#> 4   S.old.   I.old.     infection.old.old per_capita
#> 5 I.young. S.young.         waning.young. per_capita
#> 6   I.old.   S.old.           waning.old. per_capita
UserExpr(prod)$expand_vector_expressions()
#> [[1]]
#> [[1]]$output_names
#> [1] "N.young."
#> 
#> [[1]]$expression
#> [1] "sum(state[0], state[1])"
#> 
#> [[1]]$arguments
#> [[1]]$arguments[[1]]
#> [1] "state[0]"
#> 
#> [[1]]$arguments[[2]]
#> [1] "state[1]"
#> 
#> 
#> [[1]]$simulation_phase
#> [1] "during_pre_update"
#> 
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [[2]]$output_names
#> [1] "N.old."
#> 
#> [[2]]$expression
#> [1] "sum(state[2], state[3])"
#> 
#> [[2]]$arguments
#> [[2]]$arguments[[1]]
#> [1] "state[2]"
#> 
#> [[2]]$arguments[[2]]
#> [1] "state[3]"
#> 
#> 
#> [[2]]$simulation_phase
#> [1] "during_pre_update"
#> 
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [[3]]$output_names
#> [1] "dummy"
#> 
#> [[3]]$expression
#> [1] "assign(flow, 0, 0, ((((susceptibility.young. * contact.young.young) * infectivity.young.) * state[1]) / N.young.))"
#> 
#> [[3]]$arguments
#> [[3]]$arguments[[1]]
#> [1] "flow"
#> 
#> [[3]]$arguments[[2]]
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> [[3]]$arguments[[3]]
#> [1] "susceptibility.young."
#> 
#> [[3]]$arguments[[4]]
#> [1] "contact.young.young"
#> 
#> [[3]]$arguments[[5]]
#> [1] "infectivity.young."
#> 
#> [[3]]$arguments[[6]]
#> [1] "state[1]"
#> 
#> [[3]]$arguments[[7]]
#> [1] "N.young."
#> 
#> 
#> [[3]]$simulation_phase
#> [1] "during_pre_update"
#> 
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [[4]]$output_names
#> [1] "dummy"
#> 
#> [[4]]$expression
#> [1] "assign(flow, 2, 0, ((((susceptibility.young. * contact.young.old) * infectivity.old.) * state[3]) / N.young.))"
#> 
#> [[4]]$arguments
#> [[4]]$arguments[[1]]
#> [1] "flow"
#> 
#> [[4]]$arguments[[2]]
#> [1] 2

#> [[4]]$arguments[[3]]

#> [1] "infectivity.old."

#> [1] "during_pre_update"

#> [[5]]
#> [[5]]$output_names
#> [1] "dummy"
#> 
#> [[5]]$expression
#> [1] "assign(flow, 1, 0, ((((susceptibility.old. * contact.old.young) * infectivity.young.) * state[1]) / N.old.))"
#> 
#> [[5]]$arguments
#> [[5]]$arguments[[1]]
#> [1] "flow"
#> 
#> [[5]]$arguments[[2]]
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> [[5]]$arguments[[3]]
#> [1] "susceptibility.old."
#> 
#> [[5]]$arguments[[4]]
#> [1] "contact.old.young"
#> 
#> [[5]]$arguments[[5]]
#> [1] "infectivity.young."
#> 
#> [[5]]$arguments[[6]]
#> [1] "state[1]"
#> 
#> [[5]]$arguments[[7]]
#> [1] "N.old."
#>

#> [1] "during_pre_update"

#> [1] "dummy"
#> 
#> [[6]]$expression
#> [1] "assign(flow, 3, 0, ((((susceptibility.old. * contact.old.old) * infectivity.old.) * state[3]) / N.old.))"
#> 
#> [[6]]$arguments
#> [[6]]$arguments[[1]]
#> [1] "flow"
#> 
#> [[6]]$arguments[[2]]
#> [1] 3
#> 
#> [[6]]$arguments[[3]]
#> [1] "susceptibility.old."
#> 
#> [[6]]$arguments[[4]]
#> [1] "contact.old.old"

#> [[6]]$arguments[[5]]
#> [1] "infectivity.old."
#> 
#> [[6]]$arguments[[6]]
#> [1] "state[3]"
#> 
#> [[6]]$arguments[[7]]
#> [1] "N.old."
#> 
#> 
#> [[6]]$simulation_phase
#> [1] "during_pre_update"
prod$expr_list()$print_exprs()
#> ---------------------
#> Before the simulation loop (t = 0):
#> ---------------------
#> 1: per_capita_from ~ c(0, 0, 2, 2, 1, 3)
#> 2: per_capita_to ~ c(1, 1, 3, 3, 0, 2)
#> 3: per_capita_flow ~ c(0, 2, 1, 3, 4, 5)
#> 
#> ---------------------
#> At every iteration of the simulation loop (t = 1 to T):
#> ---------------------
#>  1: N.young. ~ sum(state[0], state[1])
#>  2: N.old. ~ sum(state[2], state[3])
#>  3: dummy ~ assign(flow, 0, 0, ((((susceptibility.young. * contact.young.young) * 
#>       infectivity.young.) * state[1])/N.young.))
#>  4: dummy ~ assign(flow, 2, 0, ((((susceptibility.young. * contact.young.old) * 
#>       infectivity.old.) * state[3])/N.young.))
#>  5: dummy ~ assign(flow, 1, 0, ((((susceptibility.old. * contact.old.young) * 
#>       infectivity.young.) * state[1])/N.old.))
#>  6: dummy ~ assign(flow, 3, 0, ((((susceptibility.old. * contact.old.old) * 
#>       infectivity.old.) * state[3])/N.old.))
#>  7: per_capita ~ (state[per_capita_from] * flow[per_capita_flow])
#>  8: total_inflow ~ groupSums(per_capita, per_capita_to, state_length)
#>  9: total_outflow ~ groupSums(per_capita, per_capita_from, state_length)
#> 10: state ~ ((state - total_outflow) + total_inflow)
